case_name: Rev. Father Monteiro v. Union of India

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1968. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 7, 1967 of Judicial Commissioner Court, Goa, Daman and Diu in Criminal Revision Petition No. 55 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1967 of the Judicial Commissioner Court, Goa, Daman ,and Diu in Criminal Revision Petition in No. 55 of 1966.

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro is resident of Goa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant  Rev. Father Monteiro  is a resident of Goa. After the annexation of Goa by India,

facts.text: After annexation of Goa by India, Rev. Father Monteiro chose Portuguese nationality and was registered as a foreigner.

anchor.surface_text: After the annexation of Goa by India, he had the choice of becoming an Indian national or retaining Portuguese nationality. He choose the latter and was registered as a foreigner.

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro obtained temporary residential permit allowing stay in India till November 13, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: He also obtained a temporary residential permit which allowed him to stay on in India till November 13, 1964. The period of stay expired and he did number ask for its extension or renewal.

facts.text: Period of stay expired and Rev. Father Monteiro did not ask for extension or renewal.

anchor.surface_text: The period of stay expired and he did number ask for its extension or renewal. He was ordered to leave India by the Lt. Governor of Goa.

facts.text: Lt. Governor of Goa ordered Rev. Father Monteiro to leave India on June 19, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On his failure to apply for a renewal of the permit the order of the Lt. Governor was passed on June 19, 1965.

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro disobeyed the order and was prosecuted under S. 14 read with S. 3(2)(c) of the Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: He was ordered to leave India by the Lt. Governor of Goa. ... Rev. Father Monteiro disobeyed the order, and in companysequence was prosecuted under S. 14 read with s. 3  2   c  of the Foreigners Act.

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro convicted and sentenced to 30 days simple imprisonment and fine of Rs. 50 or 5 days further simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyvicted and sentenced to 30 days simple imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 50/-  or 5 days further simple imprisonment . He appealed unsuccessfully to the Court of Session

facts.text: Appeal to Court of Session unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: He appealed unsuccessfully to the Court of Session and his revision application to the Court of the judicial Commissioner, Goa also failed.

facts.text: Revision to Judicial Commissioner, Goa failed on August 7, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: and his revision application to the Court of the judicial Commissioner, Goa also failed. He number appeals by special leave of this Court against the order of the Judicial Commissioner, Goa dated August 7, 1967.

facts.text: Defence of Rev. Father Monteiro: protected by Geneva Conventions Act, 1960; order of Lt. Governor ultra vires; committed no offence.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of Rev. Father Monteiro was that he was pro- tected by the Geneva Conventions Act, 1960, that the order of the Lt. Governor for his deportation was ultra vires the Act and that he had companymitted numberoffence.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner and lower courts held Geneva Conventions ceased to apply after Goa became part of India; no redress in Municipal Courts against Act of State.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner and the two companyrts below have held, for different reasons, that the Geneva Conventions ceased to apply after Goa became a part of India and that the Municipal Courts in India can give him numberredress against an Act of State.

facts.text: Goa was Portuguese colony for about 450 years.

anchor.surface_text: To understand the case, a brief history of the annexation of Goa and what happened thereafter is necessary. Goa was a Portuguese companyony for about 450 years,

facts.text: On December 19, 1961, Goa occupied by Indian Armed Forces.

anchor.surface_text: having been seized by force of arms. On December 19, 1961 Goa was occupied by the Indian Armed Forces following a short military action.

facts.text: From December 20, 1961, Goa under Indian Administration.

anchor.surface_text: It then came under Indian Administration from December 20, 1961 and was governed under the Goa, Daman and Diu  Administration  Ordinance 1962

facts.text: Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Ordinance 1962 promulgated by President of India.

anchor.surface_text: and was governed under the Goa, Daman and Diu  Administration  Ordinance 1962 promulgated by the President of India. Under the Ordinance all authorities were to companytinue performing their functions

facts.text: Ordinance replaced by Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Act 1 of 1962, enacted March 27, 1962, came into force March 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was later replaced by an Act of Parliament bearing the same title and numbered as Act 1 of 1962. It was enacted on March 27, 1962 and came into force from March 5, 1962.

facts.text: Constitution Twelfth Amendment Act, 1962 enacted March 27, 1962, deemed into force December 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It re-enacted the provisions of the Ordinance and in addition gave representation to Goa in Parliament amending for the purpose the Representation of the People Act. The same day  March 27, 1962 , the Constitution  Twelfth Amendment  Act, 1962 was enacted and was deemed to have companye into force on December 20, 1961.

facts.text: Citizenship Act 1955, Foreigners Act 1946, Registration of Foreigners Act 1939 extended to Goa.

anchor.surface_text: Many Acts it,. force in India were then extended to Goa and many Regulations and Orders were promulgated. Among the Acts so extended were the Citizenship Act of 1955, the Foreigners Act 1946 and the Registration of Foreigners Act, 1939.

facts.text: Goa, Daman and Diu Citizenship Order 1962 promulgated under S.7 of Citizenship Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government also promulgated under S. 7 of the Citizenship Act, 1955, the Goa, Daman and Diu  Citizenship  Order 1962 and as it directly companycerns the present matter

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro made declaration of Portuguese nationality on April 27, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this Order, on April 27, 1962, Rev. Father Monteiro made his declaration of Portuguese nationality and on August 14, 1964 applied for a residential permit.

facts.text: Rev. Father Monteiro applied for residential permit on August 14, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this Order, on April 27, 1962, Rev. Father Monteiro made his declaration of Portuguese nationality and on August 14, 1964 applied for a residential permit.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant concedes legality of military action and annexation.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset it may be stated that Mr. Gardner companycedes that he does, number question the legality of the military action or the annexation. In fact, he is quite clear that we may companysider the annexation to be legal.

facts.text: Court holds occupation ceased on December 20, 1961 with true annexation by conquest and subjugation.

anchor.surface_text: We can only take the critical date of true and final annexation as December 20, 1961 when the entire government and administration were taken over and there was numberarmy in occupation -and numberarmy in opposition.

facts.text: Indian Government offered Rev. Father Monteiro Indian nationality which he refused and retained Portuguese nationality.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Government offered Rev. Father Monteiro Indian nationality and citizenship which he refused and retained his Portuguese nationality.

facts.text: As Portuguese national, Rev. Father Monteiro could only stay in India with permit.

anchor.surface_text: As a Portuguese national he companyld only stay in India on taking out a permit. He was, therefore, rightly prosecuted under the law applicable to him.

holdings.text: The Geneva Conventions Act gives no specific right to any one to approach the Court.

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the Geneva Conventions Act gives no specific right to any one to approach the Court. The Act was passed under Art. 253 of the Indian Constitution read with entries 13 and 14

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act passed to implement international conventions via Art. 253; provides penalties for breaches but no individual cause of action or enforceable remedy against government.

holdings.text: Occupation in Articles 47 and 49 means belligerent occupation which ceases upon true annexation by conquest and subjugation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Belligerent occupation is temporary de facto control by hostile army (Hague Reg. Art. 42); ends with total defeat, subjugation, no opposition; distinguished from premature annexation during hostilities; facts show immediate takeover, no resistance post-Dec 19, 1961.

holdings.text: Articles 47 and 49 of the Geneva Conventions do not apply as there was no occupied territory after December 20, 1961.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Protections against deprivation of benefits or deportation apply only during belligerent occupation; true annexation ends occupation, rendering articles inapplicable.

holdings.text: The application of the Foreigners Act, the Registration of Foreigners Act and the Orders passed under them, to Rev. Father Monteiro was legally competent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the application of the Foreigners Act, the Registration of Foreigners Act and the Orders passed under them, to Rev. Father Monteiro was legally competent. A considerable body of writers on International Law support the proposition and it is sufficient to refer only to Oppenheim Vol. 1 pp. 675/676

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sovereign territorial supremacy includes right to regulate aliens' entry, residence, eviction; acts extended to Goa post-annexation; appellant registered as Portuguese national/foreigner.

holdings.text: The Geneva Conventions ceased to apply after December 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Geneva Conventions ceased to apply after December 20, 1961. The Indian Government offered Rev. Father Monteiro Indian nationality and citizenship which he refused and retained his Portuguese nationality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-annexation and end of occupation, municipal law (Foreigners Act) governs; no breach of Conventions as protections lapsed.

holdings.text: As a Portuguese national he could only stay in India on taking out a permit. He was, therefore, rightly prosecuted under the law applicable to him.

anchor.surface_text: As a Portuguese national he could only stay in India on taking out a permit. He was, therefore, rightly prosecuted under the law applicable to him. Since no complaint is made about the trial as such, the appeal must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit expired without renewal; disobeyed valid Lt. Governor order under Foreigners Act s.14 r/w s.3(2)(c); conviction upheld.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to pronounce opinion on whether the order is an Act of State as prior holdings dispose of the case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary in light of holdings on end of occupation and inapplicability of Geneva protections.

precedents.cited_proposition: The laws of belligerent occupation apply only during actual warfare and cease after total defeat of the enemy
precedents.cited_holding: laws of belligerent occupation apply only to an occupation during the course of actual warfare and once the enemy has been totally defeated those laws do not apply to the ensuing occupation
